1.title: Precursor to chords: Intervals
1.point: Intervals refer to the distance between two notes. This distance affects how the two notes sound together. Intervals are said to be made of a number of half and/or whole steps
1.explanation1: They are keys which are "right next to each other" on a piano/keyboard. Either 2 white/black keys (as shown in blue), or a white and a black key (as show in red)
1.explanation2: They are keys which are two keys apart on the keyboard. Either 2 white/black keys (as shown in blue), or a white and a black key (as show in red)

2.title: Chords
2.point: Chords are combinations of three (or four) notes with specific intervals between each note, which create a certain signature sound. Chords are created from a combination of two different intervals: Minor Thirds and Major Thirds
2.subtopic1: A minor third consists of 3 half steps
2.subtopic2: A major third consists of 4 half steps

3.title: Chords (Cont.)
3.point: There are four different types of chords: Major, Minor, Augmented, Diminished. We will mostly cover major & minor chords today
3.subtopic1: Major chords are created from a major chord (in green), followed by a minor chord (in purple)
3.subtopic2: Minor Chords are created from a minor chord (in purple), followed by a major chord (in green)

4.title: Quick aside: Keys
4.point1: The key defines what scale underlies/defines the song. For a note to be "diatonic" to a key means that the note belongs in the scale; The first note of a key/scale is known as the "root"
4.point2: There are two general types of Keys: Major and Minor: Major scales are defined by the interval pattern of: W W H W W W H (Play); Minor scales are defined by the interval pattern of: W H W W H W W (Play)
4.point3: So why do keys matter in our learning? The same progression can sound slightly different based on the song's key—focus on the music's overall vibe/shape, rather than a direct 1-to-1 comparison

5.title: Chord Progressions
5.point1: What are chord progressions? Chord progressions are a sequence of chords (commonly four chords) which define the sound of a song
5.point2: How do we notate chord progressions
5.point3: The root of the song's key is notated with the roman numeral for 1 (I), and this follows for all other notes (VII, or 7, notating the "last" note in the key's corresponding scales; Each note in the song's key has a corresponding chord—notated with lowercase if the chord is minor, and uppercase if the chord is major
